channel.title: Bcel getType in NEWARRAY i dont understand
channel.description:
I know this is a very stupid question probably you will tell me to look at javadocs for this, but I did that and cannot figure it out.
I am using bcel and I ran into a problem I don't know how to get around it..
the bytecode instruction is. [code]//44 newarray 10 (int)[/code]
which is int[];
I can check if it matches like this [code]return instruction instanceof NEWARRAY;[/code]
but it matches any array how I match only int type..
I could do
[code]return instruction instanceof NEWARRAY && ((NEWARRAY)instruction).getTypecode() == 10;[/code]
How do I do it without using magic number 10.. like Type.INT for example..
but that doesn't work on int[].. only on int's ya......
Is there a program that transforms bytecode to BCEL code?
I was thinking maybe it's something like ArrayType.INT but that doesn't seem to exist.
What I think I need is the [code]ArrayType.getBasicType() == Type.INT[/code]
Then I run into a problem how I make NEWARRAY getType() return ArrayType?
I know ArrayType extends ReferenceType which extends Type itself, but that doesn't help me much I cannot figure out how to use it.

item.title: Bcel getType in NEWARRAY i dont understand
item.dc:creator: @sspoke sspoke
item.description:
@sspoke wrote:

[quote=“Ollie, post:10, topic:410455”]I didn’t think you can do

as in the Type class there is no getBasicType() method, which version of BCEL are you using?

ref: http://commons.apache.org/bcel/apidocs/org/apache/bcel/generic/Type.html

so:

getBasicType() is part of ArrayType http://commons.apache.org/bcel/apidocs/org/apache/bcel/generic/ArrayType.html

Yeah i’m doing some project RS related.

Thanks alot guys, seems like getType() is more expensive to use then getTypecode for arrays.

yah i learned that lesson the hard way… never compare strings using == operator as you will run into a bug that will really give you a headache always use equals(). Only use == for reference checking/number checking or null checking only. Got to loop string characters to be 100% sure. or equals().

Read full topic
item.source: Bcel getType in NEWARRAY i dont understand

item.title: Bcel getType in NEWARRAY i dont understand
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

Besides, Ollie, your way would fail using ==, as they're separate instances; you'd need to use ArrayType.equals():
[code]
       /** @return true if both type objects refer to the same array type.
         */
        public boolean equals( Object _type ) {
            if (_type instanceof ArrayType) {
                ArrayType array = (ArrayType) _type;
                return (array.dimensions == dimensions) && array.basic_type.equals(basic_type);
            }
            return false;
        }
[/code]

Besides, Ollie, your way would fail using ==, as they’re separate instances; you’d need to use ArrayType.equals():

       /** @return true if both type objects refer to the same array type.
         */
        public boolean equals( Object _type ) {
            if (_type instanceof ArrayType) {
                ArrayType array = (ArrayType) _type;
                return (array.dimensions == dimensions) && array.basic_type.equals(basic_type);
            }
            return false;
        }

Read full topic

item.title: Bcel getType in NEWARRAY i dont understand
item.dc:creator: @sspoke sspoke
item.description:
@sspoke wrote:

yeah… but I want to check if the instruction NEWARRAY is type of int array. without using getTypecode == 10 any way around that? I’d also like to avoid doing a string check like getType("[I").

Actually my question is how do I use this function… (That function is from NEWARRAY)

public final Type getType() 
{
    return new ArrayType(BasicType.getType(type), 1);
}

which Type do I compare it against? to check for Type.INT

I gotta do

ya??

if thats the case i guess i’ll stick to getTypecode().
